reviewText: While Eulogy isn't the funniest film out there, it definitely isn't the worst.  Riding somewhere in mediocre-town the major issue that I had with this film was the fact that it would not "go the distance".  Let me explain.  Here you had this film that carried some pretty big names in their own respective careers and a story that was actually emotionally and humanly interesting, but unfortunately director Michael Clancy just didn't push himself to the full extent of this project's potential.  There were so many times during this film that I was prepared for a huge laugh from Romano or Azaria or even Winger, but somehow it just didn't come.  The sad part is that the build up was there, but there was no delivery.  It was as if it was planned to have a bigger moment, but either due to sloppy editing or just a poor sense of humor, it never happened.  The ending is the perfect example.  Here you have one of the weakest endings to a film imaginable.  What could have been actually quite hysterical fell to the wayside of cliché and predictable.  I wasn't happy at all with the ending to this film because it just didn't fit with the overall tone of the rest of the film.  It had the markings of a very dark comedy, but yet it never went fully dark.  It seemed to side with lightness, and it just didn't work.Outside of this dismal aspect, I would have to say that the rest of the film was very good.  The actors were exceptional.  I found myself laughing more at Romano during this film than I did when he was in Welcome to Mooseport.  This just was more unlike his Everyone Loves Raymond character that it was very appealing to watch.  Winger was also directly on cue with her character, keeping us on edge while making us chuckle at the same time.  Sadly, it was her character that suffered the most by the ending.  Her moment is left semi-visionary that just didn't work in my book.  Azaria does his job with the greatest of ease while bringing some (just not a lot) of layers to his character.  Zooey was one of my favorite characters just because it was enjoyable to see a sane one in the group.  She is the one that really is the central focus of this family, and the one that helps bring about the final climax.  She has a hefty character with big responsibility and pulls it off very well.  These were my favorite characters of the film. While there were others, I thought that these four deserved the most recognition due to their offbeat humor and impressionable characters.It wasn't until after I watched this film that I realized the Death of a Salesman references.  They were abundant throughout the entire film (through direction mentioning and smaller innuendoes), but it wasn't until Rip Torn appeared on screen that I fully understood what director Michael Clancy wanted to do.  I saw this film as a modern loosely adapted version of Arthur Miller's play.  From the salesman that couldn't sell to the child that found success early, it became very clear that Miller's play had a big influence on Clancy's project.  I would watch the film again just to catch more of the references, but it was this "oh yea" moment when you realize the truth that really brought this picture closer together.  It was a perfect match for this film and while I cannot credit much to Clancy, I can give him partial credit for creativity.  He mixed current culture into Salesman and crafted a very poignant picture that presses on the fact that children will always be children no matter what kind of family you have.Overall, I liked this film, but felt that it could have been much darker.  If only Clancy would have taken it one step further, he would have had an instant cult classic.  Looking back on it now, I hated the ending.  It left this sour taste in my mouth that tarnished the rest of the film, but after realizing the Death of a Salesman connection, I think I would go back and watch it one more time.  I do not think that it is one of the greatest films of the year, but it had potential.  I am grinding my teeth thinking about the moments that could have been literally hysterical if only Clancy would have gone further.  He cheapened out, and sadly I cannot forgive him for it on this film.  He had the right elements, he just never used them.  Eulogy was the perfect example of a good film, but with bad delivery (and packaging ... what does the fishbowl on the box have anything to do with the film?).Grade: **** out of *****
summary: She's adding ingredients to her personality.

reviewText: Insulting. Idiotic. Insipid. Inane. I endured sitting through this DVD just waiting for, hoping for, one glimmer of a cohesive script, or an entertaining storyline. With its fractured scene changes, its offensive overuse of swear words, even by the child actors, its clumsy attempts at forced humor, "Eulogy" would best be laid to rest in a deep, dark grave of its own.

reviewText: The movie Eulogy, directeed by Michael Clancy, is a fun little romp through one of the most dysfuntional families I have seen in awhile. Clancy has been able to gather together a star studded and multi-talented cast. Katie (Zooey Deschanel) is asked by her grandmother (Piper Laurie) to give the eulogy at her grandfather's (Rip Torn) funeral. Now Katie weaves from family member to family member to find something good to say about her grandfather.....and in the process finds the answer in the sweetest way.Deschanel is charming and her sweetness to do right is paired up nicely with love struck Ryan (Jesse Bradford) whose roguish smile enhances the pairs innocence. The couple act as the only sanity for the viewer while a hurricane of drama and insanity swirl about.Debra Winger gives a fine performance as a supressed housewife with a few secrets of her own and Ray Romano and his hoodlum sons work comic mayhem all over. Kelly Preston and Famke Janneson (two of Hollywood most under appreciated actresses) turn up the heat and comic meter as the lesbian sister and her life partner. Lastly, Hank Azaria is Kate's father and is the peacemaker / seedy actor/ pot smoker who seems to have a lot for tense moments. Director Michael Clancy give a strong steering in this movie to prevent it from being dull, and over done from what it is: a simple movie about a family that has issues that come to the forefront....they just so happen to come to the surface in the craziest ways. Definately a movie you will want to watch with the family and your closest friends.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed watching EULOGY, a dark comedy about a family who is reunited when the male patriarch of the family passes away.  To be honest, when I saw the cast and the well-trodden plot description, I was not expecting anything stellar.  But the film exceeded my expectations and manages to find some breathing room and originality in its short 91 minutes.  The plot of EULOGY, as every reviewer has described, is not complex.  Director Michael Clancy manages to pull you into the dysfunctional lives of these characters and let you be a fly on the wall to their hilarious and ridiculous fights.One interesting aspect of the film is its treatment of death.  You don't always expect to have any serious message coming from a comedy, but EULOGY has one.  While everyone has come to this funeral on the pretense of mourning their father, the occasion becomes a time for them all to mourn their own lives and failures.  It is a natural message enough: obviously, a death in the family makes one painfully aware of one's own mortality.  However, there is something added in this film.  No one seems to be truly sorry to see the old man go, except the granddaughter who seems to have a distorted view of him.  Perhaps, the fact that they have all gathered to "honor" the death of a man they did not openly love forces them to realize the lack of love and connection they have in their own lives.  Will we be mourned at the end of our lives?Now, I am not trying to sift EULOGY for some deep meaning or message.  But hidden behind all of the comedy and the hilarious (and absurd) dialogue, there is some real emotion to be had in these scenes.  Having not expected any, I was surprised and pleased by the end result.  My only major criticism of the film is the forced love story between the granddaughter and an old fling of hers.  It seems tacked onto the film unnaturally and serves only to snap the teenager out of her false world of mourning to join the rest of her family.  If you have the opportunity to see it, I would highly recommend this film to you.
summary: Hilarious & Interesting Dialogue Support this Sleeper

reviewText: Weddings and funerals provide the perfect venue for black humor -- family members who detest and generally avoid one another forced to be together for a brief period of time, during which they get to take their cheap shots. Anyone from a dysfunctional family -- Aren't we all? -- will recognize aspects of their relatives and themselves in this very funny film.The reason I gave it only four stars instead of five is that the producers gave in to that old Hollywood urge to have a happy ending where all previous hatreds and misunderatandings are forgiven and the family members stroll off arm-in-arm into the sunset. Urrrppp!Aside from "The Loved One" (which has just come out on DVD) and "Harold and Maude," I'm not aware of any other black humor comedies about funerals. Two about weddings that are worth watching are "Muriel's Wedding" and Robert Altman's "A Wedding."

reviewText: DVD is the best thing since slice bread because if you missed a movie cause you're too busy you can always catch it on DVD, and Eulogy is probably one of those movies that people won't go out of their ways to see in their local theather but can appreciate on DVD.  It's an over the top treatment of a disfunction American family with a funeral thrown in.  The only sane, respondsible character is grandaughter Kate(Zooey Deschane-looking like a younger version of Winger) who tries to keep waring aunts, kooky grandma, divorced/oversexed uncle and pot smoking dad from killing each other while trying to compose a eulogy for her much loved grandfather(Rip Torn). The movie doesn't hold back in the insanity department, everyone is crazy and off the chain, even the lascivious 12yr twin nephews and the poor widowed grandma who with acute depression, can't seem to off herself properly.  It gets better at the funeral when Debra Winger walks to the piano seeming like she was gonna sing something funeral-like apropriate song, but instead she sings "I am not in love, but I'm open to persuation, east or west where's the best for romancing with a friend, I can smile" ofcourse this is dedicated to the Glenne Headly character, a friend from high school, which she sorta re-kindles a long ago "romance " What's it got to do with a funeral? I don't know but it was funny. What a crack up! You might not like the whole movie but a lot of parts are pretty funny.  I laughed.

reviewText: I rented this movie because Ray Romano was one of the main characters. It turns out he doesn't have a huge role, nonetheless it is an entertaining comedy. The movie throws a dysfunctional family together for the grandfather's funeral. And by dysfunctional I mean that these guys make your family look normal! I give the writers a lot of credit for creating such original and convoluted characters. Yet, it's also impossible not to laugh with them as they confront the ghosts of an absentee parent. If you like outrageous family comedies, this isn't a bad bet.

reviewText: This movie provides a few good laughs and quite a few cringes but overall it's not bad.  If you come from a large family, you know how the big reunions can be whether for a funeral or some other event.  Everyone has their role to fill - bossy older sister, favorite son, black sheep, screw-up, etc.  The thing is that no one is all good or all bad.  If we could all just see the real person inside, maybe some of the all too familiar battles could be averted.  The Collins family has to learn some of this the hard way as they gather to mourn their father who is not so dearly departed.  The granddaughter is struggling to write a Eulogy and can't seem to come up with any good stories about her grandpa from the rest of the family.  As each one remembers their childhood, the old wounds reopen.  They are forced to reexamine their lives and their own happiness.  It ends on a good note and really makes you think about the happy times you have had with your own family.  It's not the funniest funeral movie I've ever seen.  Death at a Funeral beats this one hands down but Eulogy isn't bad.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's been done before, but featuring some very sad thirty-somethings, not a sadly funny dysfunctional family.  Dad (Rip Torn) - hardly known by his children - dies and the children assemble with mom (Piper Laurie) for the funeral.  Over the course of the few days before the funeral, the children (Ray Romano, Hank Azaria, Kelly Preston and a resurrected Debra Winger) who haven't seen each other - and clearly don't much like each other, engage in various joustings.  Our "control" is "Kate"(Zooey Deschanel) daughter of Hank Azaria's "Daniel."  The only really "sane" one, Zooey tries to make sense of it all and we see things through her eyes.  (There is a romantic sidebar for her with "Ryan.")  There is a (very mildly) surprising ending.  The movie is simply an amusing ensemble comedy without notable performances with the exception of Romano and Laurie.  (Romano's "Skip's" two sons are quite funny.)  Winger shows signs of returning to form, but don't expect anything great here.  (Rip Torn appears in a video.  Too bad:  great actor.)  This is the kind of movie you rent when you hit Blockbuster way too late on Friday, but you've got to see a movie.  Don't expect much and it won't disappoint you.

reviewText: Odd that one of the recurring themes for television series, plays,  cartoons, and movies is the American dysfunctional family.  Odd, and sad that what in previous years used the same concept for meaty tough dramas like, for one example, O'Neil's 'Long Days Journey into Night'.  Now those same issues that used to be private and painful and not concepts that families would openly share with a public have become fodder for zany, over the top, toilet-mouthed comedies.Such is the case for EULOGY.  In essence the story is a matter a few days in the Collins family whose three generations have gathered for the funeral of the patriarch Edmund Collins (Rip Torn), each with their own issues of disenchantment with the world and each caught up in the ME FIRST pathology that precludes healthy relationships - save one: granddaughter Kate (Zooey Deschanel) daughter of ex-child actor Daniel (Hank Azaria) who seems the most solidly adjusted of the bunch and is therefore the one elected to write and speak the Eulogy for the funeral.The Grandmother Charlotte (Piper Laurie) is suicidal (who wouldn't be in this family environment?) and the remainder of the family includes smarmy Skip (Ray Romano playing Ray Romano), Skip's twin sons Fred and Ted (Curtis and Keith Garcia), lesbian sister Lucy (Kelly Preston) and her lover Judy (Famke Janssen),and the controllingly vile sister Alice (Debra Winger).  Throw these disparate characters into the bowl, add the fishfood script by Michael Clancy (who also directs) and voila! - out comes a fast-paced, half-baked comedy that finds the audience hungry for laughter even over embarrassing choices of jokes.  The cast is fleshed out with performances from Glenne Headly, Jesse Bradford, and Rene Auberjonois.Yes, the film has its funny moments: it is sad that the comedy is always at the expense of individual character flaws that are not inherently funny.  But with a cast of this quality you can be assured that the project is worth watching, if only to see the talented Debra Winger once again in action!  Grady Harp, March 05
summary: Life in a Fish Bowl - a Family in Full View

reviewerName: J. Conn "Wife, Mom, Doula, Big Geek"
reviewText: This movie, with a stellar cast and a oft-used plot (dysfunctional family reuniting for a funeral), was one of those movies where you are laughing while you say "oh that is just wrong!"  Four adult children of a traveling salesman come together with their various children and significant others gather at their grieving mother's house, and clash in various ways. Zooey Deschanel is the main character, a college student trying to write a Eulogy for her grandfather, when she is apparently the only one in her family with pleasant memories of him.  Everyone is so busy with their own problems that the fact their father/grandfather has died gets lost in the mix.There are great bizarre moments, some hilarious one-liners and a few surprisingly touching moments (but just a few).  This movie kept me laughing and I highly recommend it. It'll make your family look normal.
Title: N/A

reviewText: There are very few films I will not watch through their entirety.  Usually movies give me little glimmers of hope that somewhere -- sometime -- there will be a moment that made the movie worth watching.Sad to say, I couldn't find that moment a mere 1/2 hour into the movie, so I shut it off. **(see note below)  Part of me thinks, "Gee, I should have given it longer," but then the other part of me thinks, "Life is too short."  I rented this movie on the basis of its supposedly dynamite cast, who, unfortunately, act in this movie as if its their first acting job and they're trying really hard to impress the director.  Overacting -- it sucks.The twins were sugary and nauseating.  It wouldn't have been so bad if either one of them was remotely believable.  Their stupid utterances were cliched and worn.  I found myself rolling my eyes whenever they popped up on screen.  They were not cute, they did nothing to move the story along, and their characters were cardboard from the get-go.I love Ray Romano, so I was determined to stick it out for this movie.  Even he couldn't save it for me.  The moustache looked ridiculous and I found his character hopelessly one-dimensional.The rest of the cast seemed nondescript as well.  I understand that this family was dysfunctional, but their whole arrival at the house was so far-fetched.  You can't tell me that any family would come together with nary a greeting, just settling comfortably into their horribly cliched roles.:::Yawn:::I am totally amazed at all the reviews praising this drivel for its "dark comedy."  If you mean "dark comedy" in the sense that the movie is so bad that it's hard to see the light at the end of the tunnel, then you'd be correct.  This movie remained as black as midnight for the eons that it seemed I had it playing.** After I wrote this review, I actually did go back and watch the movie in its entirety to see if I was missing the point.  It's safe to say that I wasn't.  This supposedly "dark comedy" misuses the comedic actors it had at its disposal; not only are they not memorable, but they're not funny, original, or meaningful.  In my opinion, a good dark comedy is a movie like Fargo, where the characters become icons for their originality.  No originality in Eulogy, sad to say.
summary: I gave it TWO chances.  Big waste of time!

reviewText: Watching this film was borderline painful. I could see where M. Clancy was heading but his lack of directoral expertise just glowers throughout this film. I chuckled a few times, but I chuckle at work too and get paid for it. The wince factor during "heavy" scenes where acting is required is high, making this film completely unbelievable even with a healthy suspension of disbelief. Also, M. Clancy, if in the odd chance you're reading this, the last time I checked, re-writes were not against the law.If your soul is in need of a character study with a funeral backdrop, rent or buy Lawrence Kasdans classic "The Big Chill." You'll be much better off for it.
summary: How do these crappy films continue to get made?

reviewText: In spite of an excellent performance by Debra Winger--who is the standout here (her best work in years)--and a few genuinely funny spots here and there, Eulogy is not a strong comedy. For the most part the acting is fine; also worth mentioning are Piper Laurie and Famke Janssen, with Ray Romano intermittently supplying some great crude humor. (The women really carry this film, and they do a great job, overall).The problem is the script which goes from character to character and reveals some of their quirks, but forsakes social bite in favor of quick set pieces that are used to supply zingers and superficial regret sound bites, but nothing of real substance, even comedically. Contrast this with Down and Out in Beverly Hills which focuses on a situation around which the dysfunctional family rallies in the various dysfunctional ways they know how. This was undoubtedly supposed to be the objective of Eulogy, but the writer-director fell short because the focus is just not strong enough.The "scenelet" in the courtroom with Romano is hilarious. The occasional comments of his two twin sons, as crude as their father, are also really funny, here and there. But this is not a consistently good comedy which is too bad; it definitely could have been much better if there had been a greater emphasis on the MEANING of the patriarch's life and death, rather than tossing off a few crumbs on this topic here and there and instead focusing, as mentioned, in a scattershot manner, on how to wring guffaws out of an audience based on a lot of lesbian stuff.Nothing wrong with lesbianism; that's not the point. The point is that the film is mistitled and mis-plotted. The premise is not solid enough to carry the film. This is not really a bad film; it's just not a great comedy.Your call.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Rip Torn (Rolling Kansas, Men In Black 1 & 2) kicks the bucket and the whole family gets together for his funeral and to see who gets what in the will. The family includes his wife played by Piper Laurie (Carrie, The Faculty) who tries to kill herself by jumping out of the car but lands on grass. There's Aunt Debra Winger (Terms of Endearment, Forget Paris) who has a silent family and she also likes women. There's Aunt Kelly Preston (Jerry Maguire, Sky High) who is a lesbian and she brings her lover Famke Janssen (GoldenEye, X-Men 1-3) along with her. There's Uncle Ray Romano (Everybody Loves Raymond, Welcome to Mooseport) who brings his twins with him and then there's Uncle Hank Azaria (The Simpsons, America's Sweethearts) who brings the Granddaughter, played by the talented and attractivly cute as hell Zooey Deschanel (Almost Famous, All The Real Girls) Deschanel is the one who is supposed to come up with the "Eulogy" hence the title. Comedy is extremely funny with great dialouge. Only thing about it is that Debra Winger is miscast. One of the best pieces of dialouge would be when Ray Romano tells everyone that when he dies he wants to be creamated and mixed in with the stuff that prints money, so when they mix his ashes in with the ink and print them on dollars, he'll be everywhere...great stuff. Also starring Jesse Bradford (Swimfan, Hackers), Glenne Headly (Mortal Thoughts), Vincent Castellano (Anaconda, Mulholland Dr.), Rance Howard (Cinderella Man, Happy Texas), Rene Auberjonois (Boston Legal), Paget Brewster (Lets Talk About Sex, Harvey Birdman), Mark Harelik (Election) and Brian Posehn (Devil's Rejects, Run Ronnie Ron).
summary: Zooey Deschanel has to come up with a "Eulogy" in Eulogy
Title: N/A

reviewText: EULOGY is blessed with a marvelous cast, and its darkly comic undertone is at times realistic and often over the top.  But it's performed with such vigor and flair from its talented cast, one can't help but find it amusing.  Although there isn't a character in the movie who is totally likeable, you can almost sense the agony underlying its dysfunctional family.  Hank Azaria is superb as the wannabe actor whose claim to fame is a peanut butter commercial he filmed while 8 years old, and who is now working in really bad porno flicks; Jesse Bradford (Swimfan) is appropriately noble as the granddaughter's old suitor who is still fanning the flames; Zooey Deschanel's granddaughter is the one character who seems to have some worthwhile traits; Glenne Headly is great as the nurse who has her own secrets with the family; Famke Janssen does a nice turn as daughter Kelly Preston's significant other who finds little acceptance from her future in-laws; Preston herself does a nice spin as the lesbian daughter seeking support; Piper Laurie is marvelous as the mother and widow whose suicide attempts are hilarious in their own right; Ray Romano is annoying as all heck as the self-centered father of two twins from hell; Debra Winger outdoes herself as the bitchy sister whose lifelong rivalry with Preston comes to a head; and of course there's a glorified cameo from Rip Torn as the deceased father with his own secret.  Writer/director Michael Clancy keeps things moving at a good pace and while EULOGY is certainly not a pleasant experience, it is an entertaining one.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I didnt expect to enjoy this film like I did, it's not been promotoed as far as I am aware but I think it should have been.It's the story of a young girl Kate (Zooey Deschanel) whos grandfather (Rip Torn) has just kicked the bucket and the familly re-unite at the widows place for the funeral. Shes been asked to say a few last words at the funeral but she doesnt know what to write, and the family is not much help to ask seeing as how there a very disfunctional group.Ray Ramano (Every one loves Raymond fame) plays a single father who's a bit of a slob and has 2 kids about 12 year old that are little smart alecs and terrors. Ray & the kids proviod a few decent laughs along the way of whats probably the least most approriote thing to say in convesations and situations.Hank Azaria, Piper Laurie & Debra Winger also play parts of the family. Each member has there own little storys going on, it's filled with comedy, heart & issues.Overall I recomend you rent it, i'm suprised at reveiws dissmissing it, they are probably fans of Every One Loves Raymond and didnt like Ray playing a diffrent charactor in a disfunctional group.... this is more like what EBLR would be like if it dealt with real-life situations with drugs, smut and dark humuor.

reviewText: There are some movies that are just God awful, with horrible writing and plots that are so convoluted that you can't believe somebody put them to paper.  Most of these movies are to be avoided.  Eulogy is the exception.The material is just as bad as I described but the PERFORMANCES.  I've never seen so many actors make so much lemonade out of so many lemons.  The delightful Hank Azaria shines in yet another offbeat role (I suspect he will one day be thought of as of the great character actors of his time), Ray Romano is just plan funny, Debra Winger plays a characters whose path is so predictable (re:But I'm a Cheerleader) you can't believe the writer had the never to write it, but she pulls it off.  Rip Torn and Piper Laurie shine in their small roles and Zooey Daniel holds it all together as our eyes in this picture.  The only wasted character is played by Famke Janssen, her performance isn't bad but there just isn't much of anything done with her.This was one of the wife's movies, it was clear that it was just God awful but you just couldn't help but laugh, time and time again the actors made horrible material work and a few scenes such as the revelation concerning Zooey Daniel's mother was just classic.I don't think this one is a keeper, you might consider it a rental.  In a way I can't help but think of the tag line fromA Bronx Tale.  Wasted Talent, so much talent on such a bad script.  It this was written or plotted better it could have been a classic rather than an ok movie for a cold day.

reviewText: It appeared that some of the scenes were severely adlibbed which could have worked if the script hadn't been so weak. All of the supposed punch lines fall very flat.This movie was very unoriginal. The anti-hetero script is full of venom that is pointed directly at all of those normal fly over parts of the country. It was obvious from the word go where Debra Wingers character was going in this movie. All of the men were written as either perverts, potheads, bigamist  or just flat out weaklings. While, the majority of the women were written as frustrated lesbians. I could have appreciated this biased humor much more if the movie were even remotely funny. Which just to reiterate, it is not funny in the least.Finally, this is one cheaply made film. There is one particularly pathetic special effect late in the movie involving the old woman in mid flight. I could have done a better job on my home pc with that scene than what the film makers did here. Also, the last scene should have obviously been shot at night.No one was at the wheel here. This movie is easily as bad as the recent remake of The Stepford Wives. That's how bad it is.
summary: the opposite of funny and cheap to boot
Title: N/A
